events.description: Proto-Greek tribes are believed to have brought the cult of the sky god (Zeus) to the Balkans during migrations around 2000‚Äì1900 BC. The names of these gods appear on Linear B clay tablets dating back to 1450 BC. Mount Olympus was considered the home of the Greek gods.
events.name: Formation of the Greek pantheon

events.description: Legendary synoikismos (unification) of Attica under mythical king Theseus creates Athens as unified polis; twelve independent communities merge into single city-state centered on Acropolis with shared religious festivals and citizenship
events.name: Legendary Foundation of Athens

events.description: Thebes becomes major Mycenaean palace center in Boeotia; legendary founding by Cadmus who brought Phoenician alphabet to Greece, city associated with myths of Oedipus and Seven Against Thebes
events.name: Thebes as Mycenaean Center

events.description: A sanctuary was established on the slope of Mount Parnassus, where Gaia, the goddess of the Earth, was worshiped. A seeress (Pythia) lived at the temple, the Greeks turned to her for advice about the future. The Oracle became the most important cult phenomenon in the Hellenic world; kings and peasants sought its advice; the Oracle often received gifts from rulers, as they wished to appease the gods.
events.name: Appearance of the Oracle of Delphi

events.description: Argos emerges as dominant Mycenaean center in northeastern Peloponnese; one of oldest continuously inhabited cities in world, claiming descent from mythical founder Argus and serving as major power before and after Bronze Age collapse
events.name: Rise of Argos

events.description: Hercules' first quest. The beast lived in the mountains near the city of Nemea and hid in a cave with two exits. Hercules blocked one of the cave's openings with rocks, and when the lion emerged, he stunned it with his club and strangled it with his bare hands, as the monster's hide was impervious to arrows. Hercules later wore the lion's skin as armor.
events.name: Hercules slays the Nemean Lion

events.description: Hercules' second quest. A monstrous Hydra inhabited the Lernaean marshes and ravaged the surrounding lands. Hercules slew the many-headed monster, cauterizing the severed necks with fire to prevent the heads from growing back.
events.name: Heracles slays the Lernaean Hydra

events.description: Hercules' third labor. According to legend, he frightened man-eating birds with the noise of copper rattles given to him by Athena and shot them down with his bow.
events.name: Hercules kills the Stymphalian birds

events.description: The sixth labor of Hercules. King Augeas of Elis hadn't cleaned the stables of his thousands of horses for 30 years. Hercules was tasked with cleaning them, and he diverted the Alpheus and Peneus rivers to wash away all the filth with a stream of water.
events.name: Hercules cleaning the Augean stables

events.description: The seventh labor of Hercules. A bull was sent to King Minos by the god Poseidon as a sacrifice, but the king kept it for himself, angering the god and sending it into a frenzy. Hercules caught the bull, tamed it, and, riding on its back, swam across the sea, reaching Crete to the Peloponnese. Theseus later killed this bull at Marathon.
events.name: Hercules tames the Cretan bull

events.description: King Aegeus of Athens, Theseus's father, threw himself off the cliff of Sounion when Theseus's ship returned from Crete with black sails, a fact that Theseus had not survived the voyage. According to legend, Theseus forgot to hang out the white sail because she was saddened by the loss of Ariadne, who had abandoned him on the island of Naxos in the mechanism of the gods.
events.name: King Aegeus throws himself into the sea

events.description: According to legend, Athens was a vassal state to the Cretan king Minos. Athens was obliged to send young men and women to Crete to be sacrificed to the Minotaur. The Athenian prince Theseus voluntarily traveled to Crete as part of another group of sacrifices to slay the monster, stop paying tribute, and free Athens from this vassalage.
events.name: Theseus slays the Minotaur at Knossos

events.description: The Argo docked at the island of Lemnos to replenish its water and provisions. It turned out that the island was inhabited only by women. Aphrodite had previously punished them for their disrespect by turning their husbands away from them. Husbands began to bring slave wives from Thrace to Lemnos. In revenge, the wives killed the entire male population on the island. The Argonauts caught the eye of the women, and only the stubbornness of Heracles forced the Argo to abandon the island a year later.
events.name: The Argonauts stay on Lemnos

events.description: Jason, the centaur Chiron's prot√©g√©, was tasked to return the Golden Fleece (the hide of a magical ram) to the city of Iolcus. Golden Fleece was located in distant Colchis (modern-day Georgia). This was a condition of his usurper uncle Pelias for Jason's rightful royal throne to be restored.
events.name: The beginning of the Argonauts quest

events.description: The heroes are warmly welcomed by King Lycus, who is grateful for the Argonauts' earlier slaying of his enemy, the Bebrycian king Amycus. However, here the expedition loses its seer and helmsman.
events.name: The Argonauts are visiting the Mariandins

events.description: The Symplegades are two mythical rocks at the entrance to the Black Sea from the Bosphorus. They constantly approached and then moved apart, destroying passing ships. The seer Phineus advised the Argonauts to release a dove ahead of them. When the rocks collided and began to move apart, the Argo slipped between them, losing only the ornament on its stern. After that, the rocks remained stationary forever.
events.name: The Argonauts overcome the Symplegades

events.description: Argo arrived in the land of the Bebryces (Bithynia), ruled by King Amycus, son of Poseidon. He forced all foreigners to fight him with their fists. The Argonaut Polydeuces (one of the Dioscuri twins) accepted the challenge and slew the giant king with a well-aimed blow, after which the heroes dispersed his army.
events.name: The Argonauts defeat the king of Bithynia

events.description: Hercules broke his oar, and the Argonauts landed so that he could make a new one from suitable wood. While Hercules was busy with work, his young companion and favorite Hylas went to the spring to fetch water, where he was kidnapped by nymphs enchanted by his beauty. Hercules and Polyphemus set out in search of Hylas and failed to return in time for the Argo's departure.
events.name: The Argonauts sail away without Hercules

events.description: Having sailed through the Hellespont into the Propontis, the Argonauts were warmly welcomed by the Doliones, led by King Cyzicus. During a feast, the Argo was attacked by the giants, but the heroes fought them off. The Argo sailed at night during a storm, and the storm again drove the ship to the same shore. In the darkness, the Argonauts and the Doliones did not recognize each other; in the battle, Jason killed King Cyzicus. As a sign of their grief, the Argonauts mourned the dead for three days and held a lavish funeral.
events.name: The Argonauts meet the Doliones

events.description: Jason presented the Golden Fleece to King Pelias. However, during Jason's absence, Pelias killed his father and brought his mother to his death. Medea took cruel revenge on Pelias: she convinced his daughters that if they cut their father into pieces and boiled them in a cauldron with magical herbs, he would become younger. King Pelias died. Jason and Medea were exiled from Iolcos and fled to Corinth.
events.name: The end of the Argonauts' voyage

events.description: On their way to Greece, the Argonauts decided to dock at Crete to replenish their water supplies. But their path was blocked by Talos, a bronze giant created by Hephaestus. He circled the island three times a day, hurling enormous stones at the strangers. Medea's magic put the giant to sleep. He tripped, hit a sharp stone, injured his ankle, and fell.
events.name: The Argonauts defeat Talos

events.description: The Argonauts launched their ship into Lake Tritonia but were unable to find a way out to the Mediterranean Sea. Then Poseidon's son, Triton, came to their aid. Triton revealed a secret passage between the rocks to the heroes, then picked up a clod of dry soil and handed it to the Argonaut Euphemus. This gesture was of great symbolic significance: it granted the Greeks the right to future ownership of this land.
events.name: Triton's Gift to the Argonauts

events.description: Just as Argo was about to reach the shores of the Peloponnese, a sudden northern storm blew the ship far south. The ship was washed ashore in shallow waters in the Gulf of Sirte. The heroes found themselves in the middle of a parched desert, where Argo became mired in the sand. On the advice of the local deities, the heroes shouldered the ship and carried it for 12 days to Lake Triton.
events.name: The Argonauts reach Africa

events.description: On the island of the Phaeacians, the Argonauts were overtaken by the second part of the Colchian fleet. The local Queen Arete and King Alcinous agreed not to hand Medea over to her father only on the condition that she was already Jason's legal wife. To save themselves, the heroes performed a wedding ceremony that same night in a sacred grotto on the island.
events.name: The Marriage of Jason and Medea

events.description: The Argonauts had to pass through a narrow strait inhabited by two monsters. Scylla was a rock on the mainland (modern-day Scilla), and Charybdis was a dangerous whirlpool off the coast of Sicily (the Messina region). Strong currents and whirlpools, the prototypes of the mythical Charybdis, can still be seen in the Strait of Messina.
events.name: Between Scylla and Charybdis

events.description: The Sirens tried to lure the heroes with their singing and force Argo to crash into the rocks, but Orpheus began to play the lyre so beautifully that he drowned out their voices.
events.name: The Argonauts escape from the Sirens

events.description: According to myth, the Argonauts sailed here after the murder of Apsyrtus to undergo a rite of purification from Circe, the sister of the Colchian king Aeetes and Medea's aunt. She cleansed them of their impurity, but refused them hospitality when she learned of the monstrous nature of the crime.
events.name: The Argonauts undergo a purification ritual

events.description: The Colchian king Aeetes subjected Jason to three difficult trials, which Jason was helped to overcome by the king's daughter, the sorceress Medea. However, he still had to steal the Golden Fleece and escape from Colchis across the Danube to the Adriatic Sea (this is how the Greeks imagined a round-the-world trip). At the Brigeides, the Argonauts and Medea were overtaken by the king's son, Apsyrtus. Jason tricked Apsyrtus and killed him in the temple of Artemis.
events.name: The Argonauts kill the prince of the Colchians

events.description: According to researchers, the residence of the Colchian king Aeetes was located on the site of the modern city of Kutaisi (or its environs). The fleece was found in the sacred grove of Ares. The myth has a historical basis: in the mountains of Svaneti, an ancient method of gold mining is still practiced: ram skins are dipped into gold-bearing rivers, and the fibers of the wool trap fine grains of gold dust. After drying, such skins are literally combed, producing "golden wool."
events.name: The Argonauts retrieve the Golden Fleece

events.description: The mouth of the Phasis (Rioni) River is considered the Argonauts' arrival in Colchis. The Argonauts entered the Phasis, abandoned their ship at its mouth, and sailed upstream to the capital of Colchis.
events.name: The Argonauts arrive in Colchis

events.description: The ninth labor of Hercules. Hercules is tasked with obtaining the magical belt of the Amazon queen Hippolyta for the daughter of Eurystheus. Hippolyta knew of Hercules' labors and was ready to give him the gift, but Hera, disguised as an Amazon, provoked a conflict; thus, Hercules was forced to fight for the belt.
events.name: Hercules retrieves Hippolyta's belt

events.description: Orpheus, Greece's greatest musician, and his wife, the nymph Eurydice, were happy until Eurydice died from a snake bite. Orpheus followed her to the underworld. His singing was so beautiful that Hades and Persephone agreed to release Eurydice. However, Orpheus, when leaving, did not fulfill Hades's condition. As a result, Eurydice remained in the underworld.
events.name: Orpheus descends into Hades

events.description: At the very end of the world, Hercules killed the giant Geryon and his two-headed dog in order to steal his herd of red cows.
events.name: Hercules steals Geryon's cows

events.description: The eleventh labor of Hercules. Hercules obtained the golden apples from the Garden of the Hesperides, which in mythology was located at the very edge of the Western world. According to legend, Hercules either personally slew the hundred-headed dragon Ladon, who guarded the tree, or lifted the heavens onto his shoulders while the Titan Atlas went to fetch the apples.
events.name: Hercules obtains the apples of the Hesperides

events.description: Having become widowed, Theseus and Pirithous decided that they were only worthy of marrying the daughters of Zeus. They vowed to help each other get such brides. Helen of Troy was kidnapped for Theseus; for Pirithous, the lot fell on Persephone, Queen of the Underworld. The abduction of a goddess from the realm of the dead was considered the highest manifestation of pride. The friends descended into the underworld, where they were captured by Hades for their insolence.
events.name: Theseus descends into Hades

events.description: The twelfth labor of Hercules. Hercules is obliged to bring Cerberus from the underworld to Mycenae. Hades allows Hercules to take Cerberus, but only if he defeats the beast with his bare hands. Along the way, Hercules manages to free the captive Theseus from captivity.
events.name: Hercules descends into Hades

events.description: Greek Dark Ages begin after Mycenaean collapse; population drops by 75%, writing disappears, trade networks collapse, and Greeks revert to isolated village communities with subsistence agriculture
events.name: Greek Dark Ages Begin

events.description: Cyme (Aeolian) founded by Aeolian colonists from mainland Greece; largest and oldest Aeolian city in Asia Minor, mother city of many colonies including Italian Cumae, claimed as hometown of Hesiod's father
events.name: Foundation of Aeolian Cyme

events.description: Tenedos (Bozcaada) colonized by Aeolian Greeks; small island near Trojan coast plays strategic role in Greek mythology as hiding place for Greek fleet during Trojan War; remains important naval waystation
events.name: Aeolian Settlement of Tenedos

events.description: Smyrna founded by Aeolian colonists, later absorbed by neighboring Ionian Colophon around 688 BC; strategic location on gulf makes it major trade center; claims to be birthplace of Homer along with Chios
events.name: Foundation of Smyrna

events.description: Mytilene founded by Aeolian Greeks on Lesbos island; becomes leading city of Aeolis and major cultural center, birthplace of poets Sappho and Alcaeus, philosopher Theophrastus, and tyrant Pittacus (one of Seven Sages)
events.name: Foundation of Mytilene

events.description: Dorian Greeks establish Sparta in Laconia valley after conquering earlier Achaean population; legendary founders Eurysthenes and Procles, twin sons of Aristodemus, become first Agiad and Eurypontid kings establishing dual monarchy
events.name: Foundation of Sparta

events.description: Miletus founded by Ionian Greeks fleeing Dorian invasion; becomes preeminent city of Ionia with four harbors, establishing over 70 colonies around Black Sea and Mediterranean, birthplace of Greek philosophy and science
events.name: Foundation of Miletus

events.description: Teos founded by Ionian settlers on narrow peninsula between two harbors; birthplace of poet Anacreon and site of proposed Ionian League capital; later home to Artists of Dionysus guild of performers
events.name: Foundation of Teos

events.description: Phocaea established by Ionian colonists on small peninsula with two excellent harbors; becomes premier seafaring city of Ionia, pioneering long-distance Mediterranean trade and founding Massalia (Marseille) and other western colonies
events.name: Foundation of Phocaea

events.description: Dorian Greeks complete migration into Peloponnese, displacing earlier populations; traditionally blamed for Mycenaean collapse, though modern scholarship questions extent of invasion
events.name: Dorian Migration

events.description: Colophon established by Ionian settlers in fertile valley near Aegean coast; famous for cavalry, luxury goods, and as homeland of poet Mimnermus; oracle of Apollo at nearby Claros gains Panhellenic reputation
events.name: Foundation of Colophon

events.description: Ephesus founded by Ionian colonists led by Androclus, son of Athenian king Codrus; becomes major religious center with Temple of Artemis (one of Seven Wonders) and important trading port on Cayster River
events.name: Foundation of Ephesus

events.description: Priene founded by Ionians on slopes of Mount Mycale overlooking Maeander plain; later rebuilt in 4th century BC with famous Hippodamian grid plan, temple of Athena Polias designed by Pytheos
events.name: Foundation of Priene

events.description: Erythrae founded by Ionians on peninsula opposite Chios; one of twelve cities of Ionian League, famous for prophetess Sibylla and production of wine exported throughout Mediterranean
events.name: Foundation of Erythrae

events.description: Clazomenae founded by Ionians on small island connected to mainland by causeway; birthplace of philosopher Anaxagoras who introduced concept of nous (mind) as organizing principle of cosmos
events.name: Foundation of Clazomenae

events.description: Chios colonized by Ionians from Attica; island becomes wealthy from wine, mastic resin, and slave trade; claims to be birthplace of Homer and develops advanced democratic constitution by 6th century BC
events.name: Ionian Colonization of Chios

events.description: Samos colonized by Ionians; island becomes naval power and cultural center, home to philosopher Pythagoras, architect Rhoikos who designed Heraion temple, and engineers who built first Greek tunnel (Tunnel of Eupalinos)
events.name: Ionian Colonization of Samos

events.description: Ionians flee Dorian pressure and colonize central Aegean coast of Anatolia; twelve cities including Miletus, Ephesus and Phocaea form Ionian League, preserving Greek culture during Dark Ages
events.name: Ionian League Formation

events.description: Corinth emerges as major commercial power at isthmus connecting Peloponnese to mainland; strategic location controlling land trade route and two harbors (Lechaeum and Cenchreae) makes it wealthy trade hub
events.name: Corinth Emerges as Trade Center

events.description: Legendary poet Homer composes Iliad and Odyssey, preserving oral traditions of Trojan War and heroic age; becomes foundational texts of Greek education and identity for centuries
events.name: Homer Composes Iliad and Odyssey

events.description: Greeks adopt Phoenician alphabet adding vowels, creating first true alphabetic writing system; revolutionary innovation enables widespread literacy and democratic participation
events.name: Greek Alphabet Development

events.description: Megara emerges as independent polis between Athens and Corinth; despite small size becomes prolific colonizer, founding Megara Hyblaea, Selinunte, Byzantium, and Chalcedon - controls key trade routes
events.name: Megara as Colonial Power

events.description: Greek colonization movement begins as city-states establish settlements across Mediterranean and Black Sea; over 500 colonies founded from Spain to Crimea, spreading Greek culture and commerce
events.name: Great Greek Colonization

events.description: First recorded Olympic Games held at sanctuary of Zeus in Olympia; athletes compete in stadion foot race (192m), with winner Koroibos of Elis recorded by name - Greeks use Olympics to date events for next 1,000 years
events.name: First Olympic Games

events.description: Chalcis on Euboea leads Greek colonization alongside rival Eretria; founds colonies in Chalcidice peninsula (named after city), Sicily, and southern Italy; emerges victorious from Lelantine War with Thessalian cavalry support
events.name: Chalcis as Colonial Power

events.description: Eretria in Euboea reaches peak as major colonizing power; rivals neighboring Chalcis in Lelantine War for control of fertile Lelantine Plain; both cities found numerous colonies in Chalcidice, Italy, and Sicily
events.name: Eretria as Colonial Power

events.description: Chalcidians from Euboea found Cumae, first Greek colony on Italian mainland; establishes Greek presence in Bay of Naples, transmits alphabet to Etruscans and Romans, and serves as gateway for Greek culture to Italy
events.name: Foundation of Cumae

events.description: Milesian Greeks found Trapezus (Trebizond) on southeastern Black Sea coast; westernmost outpost of Pontic Greek settlements, remains Greek-speaking for 2,800 years until population exchange of 1923
events.name: Foundation of Trapezus (Trebizond)

events.description: Milesian colonists establish Sinope on Black Sea coast of Anatolia; becomes major trading hub and mother city of further Black Sea colonies including Trapezus; birthplace of Cynic philosopher Diogenes
events.name: Foundation of Sinope

events.description: Naxos founded by Chalcidian Greeks as first Greek colony in Sicily; sacred altar of Apollo Archegetes marks landing spot where all future Sicilian colonists made offerings before founding their cities
events.name: Foundation of Naxos (Sicily)

events.description: Corinthian colonists found Corcyra (Corfu) on island controlling entry to Adriatic Sea; becomes wealthy maritime power but bitter rivalry with mother city Corinth later triggers Peloponnesian War
events.name: Foundation of Corcyra (Corfu)

events.description: Corinth establishes Syracuse in Sicily, which becomes largest and wealthiest Greek city in western Mediterranean; population eventually reaches 500,000, rivaling Athens
events.name: Foundation of Syracuse

events.description: Poet Hesiod writes Theogony and Works and Days; Theogony systematizes Greek mythology with genealogy of gods, while Works and Days provides practical farming advice and moral instruction
events.name: Hesiod's Theogony and Works

events.description: Chalcidians from Euboea found Zancle (later Messina) at site controlling Strait of Messina; original name means 'sickle' describing harbor shape; renamed Messana by Samian settlers in 490s BC
events.name: Foundation of Zancle (Messina)

events.description: Chalcidians establish Leontini in eastern Sicily inland from Naxos; controls fertile plain famous for grain production; Gorgias of Leontini later becomes famous rhetorician who visits Athens in 427 BC
events.name: Foundation of Leontini

events.description: Chalcidians found Catana (Catania) below Mount Etna in eastern Sicily; lawgiver Charondas creates famous law code adopted by other Chalcidian colonies; city repeatedly destroyed and rebuilt due to volcanic eruptions
events.name: Foundation of Catana (Catania)

events.description: Megarian colonists found Megara Hyblaea in eastern Sicily with permission of Sicul king Hyblon
events.name: Foundation of Megara Hyblaea

events.description: Sparta conquers Messenia in First Messenian War, enslaving population as helots; Messenian helots outnumber Spartans 7:1, creating permanent military society to maintain control
events.name: Sparta Conquers Messenia

events.description: Achaean colonists found Sybaris in southern Italy; becomes fabulously wealthy from fertile land and trade, population reaches 100,000; 'Sybarite' becomes synonym for luxury
events.name: Foundation of Sybaris

events.description: Achaean Greeks found Croton in southern Italy; becomes center of Pythagorean philosophy and produces legendary Olympic athletes including Milo of Croton (6-time wrestling champion)
events.name: Foundation of Croton

events.description: Sparta founds Taras (Taranto) with Partheniai colonists (sons born to Spartan women during Messenian War); becomes wealthiest Magna Graecia city, famous for cavalry, purple dye, and later alliance with Pyrrhus against Rome
events.name: Foundation of Taras (Taranto)

events.description: Greek hoplite warfare develops with bronze armor, large round shield (hoplon), and spear; phalanx formation of citizen-soldiers replaces aristocratic chariot warfare, democratizing military service
events.name: Hoplite Warfare Revolution

events.description: Achaean Greeks found Metapontum between rival cities Taras and Sybaris in southern Italy; Pythagoras reportedly spends final years here; famous for golden grain ears depicted on coins and temple to Hera
events.name: Foundation of Metapontum

events.description: Cnidians and Rhodians found Lipara (Lipari) on volcanic Aeolian Islands; colonists establish communistic society sharing all property equally; islands provide strategic control over Tyrrhenian Sea routes
events.name: Foundation of Lipara (Lipari)

events.description: Megarian Greeks found Heraclea Pontica on southern Black Sea coast; strategically located city becomes wealthy from timber and fishing, later known for tyrant Clearchus who declares himself son of Zeus
events.name: Foundation of Heraclea Pontica

events.description: Gela founded by colonists from Rhodes and Crete on southern Sicily coast; becomes powerful city that later founds Akragas (Agrigento) and produces tyrant Gelon who defeats Carthage at Battle of Himera (480 BC)
events.name: Foundation of Gela

events.description: Megarian Greeks found Chalcedon on Asian shore of Bosphorus; called 'city of the blind' by Persian Megabazus because settlers ignored superior site of Byzantium across strait; controls rich Black Sea fishing grounds
events.name: Foundation of Chalcedon

events.description: Chalcidian Greeks found Rhegium (Reggio Calabria) on toe of Italian boot controlling Strait of Messina; along with sister city Zancle (Messina) controls vital maritime passage between Tyrrhenian and Ionian seas
events.name: Foundation of Rhegium (Reggio Calabria)

events.description: Athens replaces hereditary kingship with annual archons; nine archons elected from aristocratic families manage religious, military, and judicial affairs, beginning constitutional evolution
events.name: Athenian Archon System

events.description: Locrians from central Greece found Epizephyrian Locri in southern Italy toe; establishes first written Greek law code under lawgiver Zaleucus; birthplace of poet Nossis compared to Sappho
events.name: Foundation of Epizephyrian Locri

events.description: Byzantium founded by Megarian colonists led by Byzas; strategic location on Bosphorus controls Black Sea trade route; becomes one of wealthiest Greek cities before later transformation into Constantinople
events.name: Foundation of Byzantium

events.description: Sparta crushes Second Messenian Revolt after 20-year struggle; legendary Spartan poet Tyrtaeus composes war songs urging hoplites to 'die beautiful deaths' rather than flee battle
events.name: Second Messenian War

events.description: Cypselus becomes tyrant of Corinth, overthrowing aristocratic Bacchiad clan; under Cypselid dynasty Corinth becomes commercial powerhouse controlling trade between Aegean and western Mediterranean
events.name: Cypselus Tyrant of Corinth

events.description: Poseidonia (Paestum) founded by colonists from Sybaris; famous for three magnificently preserved Doric temples (Temple of Hera I, Temple of Athena, Temple of Hera II) that survive as finest examples of Greek architecture in Italy
events.name: Foundation of Poseidonia (Paestum)

events.description: Milesian Greeks establish Olbia (meaning 'Happy') on Bug River estuary near Black Sea; becomes major trading center exchanging Greek goods for Scythian grain, furs, and slaves; maintains Greek culture in distant steppes
events.name: Foundation of Olbia

events.description: Thales of Miletus born, first Greek philosopher; predicts solar eclipse of 585 BC, proposes water as fundamental substance, and establishes rational inquiry as alternative to mythological explanations
events.name: Birth of Thales of Miletus

events.description: Cylon attempts to become tyrant of Athens with Megarian support; seizes Acropolis but citizens refuse to join, leading to massacre of his supporters at altar - beginning of Athenian anti-tyranny tradition
events.name: Cylon's Failed Coup

events.description: Therans from Santorini found Cyrene in Libya under leadership of Battus I; becomes major Greek city in Africa, famous for silphium plant (ancient contraceptive/medicine), horses, and as birthplace of philosopher Aristippus and poet Callimachus
events.name: Foundation of Cyrene

events.description: Greeks from multiple cities establish Naukratis as trading emporium in Egyptian Nile Delta with permission of Pharaoh Psamtik I; first permanent Greek settlement in Egypt with temples to Apollo, Hera, and the Hellenion
events.name: Foundation of Naukratis

events.description: Megara Hyblaea founds Selinunte (Selinus) on southwestern Sicily coast; westernmost Greek city on island, prospers from agriculture but conflicts with Carthaginian sphere of influence; magnificent temples built before Carthaginian destruction in 409 BC
events.name: Foundation of Selinunte

events.description: Draco creates first written law code of Athens; penalties notoriously harsh (death for stealing cabbage), giving rise to term 'draconian' - but crucially establishes rule of written law over aristocratic discretion
events.name: Draco's Law Code

events.description: Massalia (Marseille) founded by Phocaean Greeks; becomes major trading hub connecting Greek world with Celtic Gaul, exporting wine and olive oil while importing tin and amber from northern Europe
events.name: Foundation of Massalia

events.description: Milesians found Panticapaeum (Kerch) on Bosporus strait connecting Black Sea to Sea of Azov; becomes capital of prosperous Bosporan Kingdom that supplies Athens with grain during Classical period
events.name: Foundation of Panticapaeum (Kerch)

events.description: Milesians found Cyzicus on Sea of Marmara isthmus connecting peninsula to mainland; becomes wealthy from tunny fishing and grain trade; Cyzicene staters become trusted currency throughout Greek world
events.name: Foundation of Cyzicus

events.description: Solon appointed archon of Athens with extraordinary powers to resolve debt crisis; cancels all debts, frees debt slaves, bans future enslavement for debt, and creates census-based constitution replacing birth with wealth as political qualification
events.name: Reforms of Solon

events.description: Thales of Miletus predicts solar eclipse, demonstrating power of rational observation; battle between Lydians and Medes halts when 'day turns to night', both sides interpreting it as divine warning to make peace
events.name: Thales Predicts Eclipse

events.description: Gela founds Akragas (Agrigento) in southwestern Sicily; becomes one of wealthiest Greek cities with magnificent temples; philosopher Empedocles hails from here; peak population of 200,000 rivaling Athens
events.name: Foundation of Akragas (Agrigento)

events.description: Phocaean Greeks found Emporion (Empuries) on northeastern Iberian coast; becomes major Greek trading post in Spain, introducing olive cultivation and coinage to native Iberians; serves as staging point for further Greek trade
events.name: Foundation of Emporion (Empuries)

events.description: Pythagoras born on Samos; later establishes philosophical school in southern Italy teaching mathematics, music theory, and transmigration of souls - discovers mathematical ratios underlying musical harmony
events.name: Birth of Pythagoras

events.description: Peisistratos seizes power in Athens as tyrant; rules benevolently, supporting farmers with loans, commissioning public works, and establishing Panathenaic festival with official text of Homer
events.name: Peisistratos Becomes Tyrant

events.description: Teans and Clazomenians found Abdera in Thrace after fleeing Persian conquest of Ionia; becomes prosperous city producing philosophers including atomist Democritus and skeptic Protagoras
events.name: Refoundation of Abdera

events.description: Originally, this site stood on the site of a Sindian (a local Scythian tribe) city called Sindik, or Sindian Harbor. Greek colonists from other cities of the Bosporan Kingdom (primarily from Miletus) transformed it into a major seaport. The city was named after Gorgippus, the brother of the Bosporan king Leucon I.
events.name: Establishing of Gorgippia

events.description: Sparta organizes Peloponnesian League, alliance system with Corinth, Elis, and other cities; members retain autonomy but follow Spartan foreign policy, creating dominant land power in Greece
events.name: Formation of Peloponnesian League

events.description: In the 7th century BC, the sanctuary was destroyed by a flood. Here begins the construction of a new, much larger temple, led by the famous architect Chersiphron and his son Metagenes.
events.name: Foundation of Temple of Artemis

events.description: Anaximander of Miletus proposes first cosmological model; Earth floats unsupported in center of cosmos, first map of known world drawn, and life originates from moisture - revolutionary naturalistic explanations
events.name: Anaximander's Cosmology

events.description: Phanagoria was founded by Ionian settlers from the city of Teos, who fled the Persian conquest of Asia Minor. The city was located on the Taman Peninsula and became one of the largest Greek colonies on the Black Sea.
events.name: Establishing of Phanagoria

events.description: The colony was founded by Phocians from Asia Minor, who left their homeland after the conquest of the Greek cities of the Asia Minor coast by Cyrus's general, Harpagus.
events.name: The founding of Elea

events.description: Thespis wins first tragic poetry competition at Athenian Dionysia; introduces actor separate from chorus, inventing dramatic dialogue - credited as inventor of theater and origin of word 'thespian'
events.name: Thespis Invents Drama

events.description: Pythagoras establishes philosophical community in Croton, southern Italy; members follow strict rules including vegetarianism, communal property, and secret mathematical-religious teachings
events.name: Pythagorean School Founded

events.description: Hippias and Hipparchus inherit tyranny of Athens from father Peisistratos; initially continue benevolent rule, but Hipparchus's assassination in 514 BC leads Hippias to brutal repression
events.name: Peisistratid Succession

events.description: Peisistratus the Younger (grandson of the tyrant Peisistratus) erected the Altar of the Twelve in Athens, thus establishing the canonical lineup of Olympian gods. The altar was considered the official center of the city. It was from this point that all distances to other settlements in Attica were measured in ancient times.
events.name: Altar of the 12 Gods in Athens

events.description: Harmodius and Aristogeiton assassinate Hipparchus at Panathenaic festival over personal grudge; later celebrated as 'Tyrannicides' and first democratic heroes, with statues in Agora
events.name: Assassination of Hipparchus

events.description: Spartan king Cleomenes I expels tyrant Hippias from Athens with army; Hippias flees to Persian court where he later guides Persian invasion at Marathon
events.name: Expulsion of Hippias

events.description: Sybaris was completely destroyed as a result of the war with Croton.
events.name: Sybaris destroyed by Croton

events.description: Cleisthenes reforms Athenian constitution creating democracy; divides citizens into ten tribes mixing regions, establishes Council of 500 by lot, and introduces ostracism to exile potential tyrants
events.name: Cleisthenic Democracy

events.description: The noble Parmenides of Elea became the founder of a new school of philosophy. The Eleatics did not study natural science, but developed a theoretical doctrine of existence. The Eleatics were conscious defenders of the unity of all existence; they also discovered profound contradictions rooted in the conventional, perceptual understanding of the universe.
events.name: Eleatic school of philosophy

events.description: Heraclitus of Ephesus develops philosophy of constant change; 'You cannot step into same river twice' and 'War is father of all things' - introduces logos as rational principle underlying apparent chaos
events.name: Heraclitus's Philosophy

events.description: Sophocles born in Colonus near Athens; will write 123 plays, winning 18 first prizes at Dionysia, and introduce third actor and painted scenery - Antigone and Oedipus Rex become theatrical immortals
events.name: Birth of Sophocles

events.description: Pericles born into aristocratic Alcmaeonid family; will dominate Athenian politics for 30 years, championing democracy, building Parthenon, and leading Athens into golden age and disastrous war
events.name: Birth of Pericles

events.description: First Persian expedition against Greece fails when fleet destroyed by storm off Mount Athos peninsula; 300 ships and 20,000 men lost, delaying Persian revenge for Sardis
events.name: Mount Athos Disaster

events.description: Athens introduces ostracism allowing citizens to vote to exile any person for ten years without trial; designed to prevent tyranny, first victim is Hipparchus son of Charmus in 487 BC
events.name: First Ostracism

events.description: Protagoras was born in Abdera. He is considered one of the first sophists. He was the first ancient Greek philosopher to charge tuition. His teaching career begins in the 450s BC. He visited Athens several times, where he became part of the inner circle of philosophers, scholars, playwrights, and other notable figures of Greece that formed around Pericles and Aspasia. Known for the phrase 'Man is the measure of all things'
events.name: The birth of Protagoras

events.description: Euripides born on Salamis; most modern of great tragedians, will write 92 plays featuring psychologically complex characters, questioning traditional values - Medea and Bacchae challenge Greek assumptions
events.name: Birth of Euripides

events.description: Themistocles persuades Athens to build fleet of 200 triremes using silver from new Laurium mine strike; controversial decision transforms Athens into naval power and saves Greece from Persian conquest
events.name: Themistocles Naval Program

events.description: Tyrant Gelon of Syracuse destroys Megara Hyblaea and enslaves population
events.name: Gelon of Syracuse destroys Megara

events.description: Neapolis (Naples) refounded by Cumaean Greeks after earlier settlement as Parthenope; name means 'New City' - becomes major center of Greek culture in Italy, maintaining Greek language and customs well into Roman period
events.name: Refoundation of Neapolis (Naples)

events.description: Aeschylus produces 'The Persians' at Athenian Dionysia, oldest surviving Greek tragedy; based on Battle of Salamis just 8 years earlier, uniquely depicts events from Persian perspective
events.name: Aeschylus 'The Persians'

events.description: Socrates born in Athens, son of stonemason and midwife; His teachings divided ancient Greek philosophy into the "pre-Socratic" and "Socratic" periods. Unlike his predecessors, who were interested in the creation of the cosmos and all things, Socrates began to study the inner world of man.
events.name: Birth of Socrates

events.description: Ephialtes and Pericles reform Areopagus, transferring most powers to Assembly and popular courts; creates radical democracy where all male citizens can speak and vote on every law and war decision
events.name: Radical Democratic Reforms

events.description: First Peloponnesian War begins between Athens and Sparta's Peloponnesian League; undeclared conflict lasts 15 years with Athens fighting on multiple fronts against Sparta, Corinth, and Aegina
events.name: First Peloponnesian War

events.description: Democritus of Abdera was one of the founders of atomism and materialistic philosophy. During his life, he traveled extensively, studying the philosophical views of various peoples (Ancient Egypt, Babylon, Persia, India, Ethiopia). Democritus developed the teachings of his mentor Leucippus on the "atom"‚Äîan indivisible particle of matter possessing true being, indestructible, and non-creating.
events.name: The Birth of Democritus

events.description: Hippocrates born on Kos island; establishes medicine as rational science separate from religion, creates Hippocratic Corpus with case studies, and formulates ethical oath still used by doctors today
events.name: Birth of Hippocrates

events.description: Aeschylus produces Oresteia trilogy at Dionysia; only complete Greek tragic trilogy surviving, follows curse of House of Atreus and establishment of Athenian jury courts over blood vengeance
events.name: Aeschylus Oresteia

events.description: Long Walls connecting Athens to Piraeus port completed; 6.5 km fortifications ensure access to sea even during siege, making Athens virtually unconquerable as long as navy controls Aegean
events.name: Athens Long Walls

events.description: In 458, the Athenian fleet won a major naval victory over the combined forces of Aegina and the Peloponnesian League, capturing 70 Aeginetan ships. Following the victory, the Athenians landed troops on the island and besieged the city of Aegina. Aegina surrendered to the Athenians after a two-year siege.
events.name: Siege of Aegina by Athens

events.description: The Spartan army invades Boeotia and achieves a tactical victory over the Athenians and their allies. The Spartans suffer losses, but force the Athenian army to retreat. Meanwhile, the Athenians block the Spartans' escape from Boeotia and, two months later, defeat the Spartans near Oenophytus.
events.name: Battle of Tanagra

events.description: Zeno of Elea formulates paradoxes challenging motion and plurality; 'Achilles and Tortoise' proves faster runner can never overtake slower, stimulating mathematical thinking about infinity
events.name: Zeno's Paradoxes

events.description: Construction of Parthenon begins on Athenian Acropolis; designed by Ictinus and Callicrates with sculptures by Phidias, temple to Athena becomes supreme achievement of Greek architecture with subtle optical refinements
events.name: Parthenon Construction Begins

events.description: The Athenian troops returning from Chaeronea fell into a well-planned ambush. Warriors from many Boeotia cities simultaneously approached the battlefield near Coronea stealthily. There was no proper battle formation. The Athenian army, spread out in a marching column, was unexpectedly struck with overwhelming force. Not a single one of the thousand Athenian hoplites escaped.
events.name: Boeotian ambush at Coronea

events.description: Thirty Years' Peace signed between Athens and Sparta ending First Peloponnesian War; recognizes dual hegemony with Sparta dominant on land and Athens controlling Aegean Sea
events.name: Thirty Years' Peace

events.description: Pericles elected strategos (general) for first of 15 consecutive years; unprecedented political dominance allows consistent policy, leading Thucydides to call Athens 'democracy in name, rule by first citizen in fact'
events.name: Pericles Dominates Athens

events.description: The Temple of Poseidon was built on the steep cliff of Sounion, the southernmost point of Attica, 60 meters above sea level. The Temple of Poseidon greeted Greek sailors returning to Athens from their voyages and served as an important landmark.
events.name: Construction of the Temple of Poseidon

events.description: Phidias completes 12-meter tall gold and ivory statue of Athena Parthenos inside Parthenon; using over 1,100 kg of gold, statue becomes symbol of Athenian wealth and piety
events.name: Athena Parthenos Statue

events.description: Parthenon completed and dedicated to Athena at Great Panathenaia; Phidias's Elgin Marbles depict procession of Athenian citizens, frieze shows gods watching festival - revolutionary integration of civic and divine
events.name: Parthenon Dedicated

events.description: Athenians found Amphipolis on strategic site controlling Strymon River gold and silver mines and timber resources; Philip II later captures it in 357 BC
events.name: Foundation of Amphipolis

events.description: Phidias completes Statue of Zeus at Olympia, one of Seven Wonders of Ancient World; 13-meter seated figure of ivory and gold on ebony throne remains at sanctuary for 800 years until destroyed by fire
events.name: Statue of Zeus at Olympia

events.description: Corcyra (Corfu) allies with Athens against Corinth, triggering chain of events leading to Peloponnesian War; Thucydides identifies this as immediate cause of great conflict between Greek powers
events.name: Corcyra Alliance

events.description: Megarian Decree issued by Athens banning Megara from all ports of Athenian empire; economic warfare designed to punish Spartan ally, Megara claims decree violates Thirty Years' Peace
events.name: Megarian Decree

events.description: Peloponnesian War begins when Thebes attacks Plataea, Athens' ally; 27-year struggle between Athenian naval empire and Spartan land alliance devastates Greece and ends Athenian golden age
events.name: Peloponnesian War Begins

events.description: Plague of Athens kills 25% of population including Pericles; disease arrives on grain ships from Egypt, spreads rapidly in crowded conditions behind Long Walls, devastating Athenian manpower and morale
events.name: Plague of Athens

events.description: Pericles dies of plague after 30 years dominating Athenian politics; his death removes moderate influence, allowing demagogues like Cleon to pursue aggressive war policies
events.name: Death of Pericles

events.description: Plato born in Athens to aristocratic family; student of Socrates, founder of Academy, and author of philosophical dialogues exploring justice, knowledge, and ideal state - Republic envisions philosopher-kings
events.name: Birth of Plato

events.description: Aristophanes produces first comedy at Athens Dionysia at age 18; 'Old Comedy' master will write 40 plays satirizing politicians, philosophers, and war - Lysistrata depicts women's sex strike for peace
events.name: Aristophanes First Comedy

events.description: Athenian general Demosthenes captures 120 Spartiate prisoners at Sphacteria; humiliating defeat shatters myth of Spartan invincibility - Spartans negotiate frantically for return of elite citizens
events.name: Battle of Sphacteria

events.description: Antisthenes of Athens founded the Cynic school. Antisthenes' mother was a slave, his father an Athenian citizen. This background made him a free citizen of Athens, but with limited civil rights. Antisthenes believed that the purpose of life was to achieve virtue and self-sufficiency (autarky). Only through self-restraint and renunciation of material possessions could a person become equal to the gods in their independence.
events.name: Athenian Cynic school

events.description: Euclid of Megara, one of Socrates' students, founded his own school of philosophy in Megara. During the conflict between Athens and Megara, he risked his life to sneak into the city at night to hear the famous philosopher. However, Euclid identified the weakest point of his teacher's method of cognition, criticizing his analogical reasoning. Unlike Socrates, he used the method of reductio ad absurdum. Euclid pioneered the study of propositional logic.
events.name: Megarian school of philosophy

events.description: The Spartan general Brasidas conquers Amphipolis, loss of city to Sparta becomes major blow to Athens
events.name: Sparta captures Amphipolis

events.description: Herodotus completes Histories, first systematic historical work; 'Father of History' records Persian Wars and digresses into customs of Egyptians, Scythians, and Persians - nine books named after Muses
events.name: Herodotus Histories

events.description: Both Cleon and Brasidas killed at Battle of Amphipolis; death of leading war advocates on both sides enables peace negotiations between Athens and Sparta
events.name: Battle of Amphipolis

events.description: Peace of Nicias signed ending first phase of Peloponnesian War; supposed to last 50 years but collapses within 6 as neither side fulfills terms, merely pausing hostilities
events.name: Peace of Nicias

events.description: Athens conquers neutral Melos, killing all adult men and enslaving women and children; Thucydides recreates Melian Dialogue showing Athenian claim that 'strong do what they can, weak suffer what they must'
events.name: Melos Massacre

events.description: Sicilian Expedition launched by Athens against Syracuse; 415-413 BC campaign becomes worst Athenian disaster with 200 ships and 40,000 men lost, breaking back of Athenian naval power
events.name: Sicilian Expedition

events.description: The Temple of Hephaestus (Hephaestion) in Athens was built over 30 years at the initiative of Pericles, as part of a large-scale program to rebuild the city after the Greco-Persian Wars. The Parthenon was built concurrently, which explains the lengthy construction period. The Temple of Hephaestus was a center of patronage for crafts. The hill of Agorƒìios Kolonos towered over the area, which in ancient times housed numerous workshops, forges, and foundries.
events.name: Construction of Hephaestion

events.description: On the advice of Alcibiades, the Spartans captured and fortified Deceleia in the last period of the Peloponnesian War, which put Athens in a very difficult position - it was a very convenient position for raids and cutting off supply routes.
events.name: Deceleia captured by the Spartans

events.description: The future philosopher Diogenes was born to the family of Hycesius, a money changer. Diogenes is known as the most famous representative of the Cynic school, preaching asceticism, independence, and disdain for social conventions.
events.name: The Birth of Diogenes

events.description: Oligarchic coup of Four Hundred briefly overthrows Athenian democracy; extremists seize power during crisis after Sicily but fleet at Samos refuses to recognize government, and democracy restored within months
events.name: Coup of Four Hundred

events.description: The Erechtheion was built on a site considered by the ancient Greeks to be the most sacred on the entire hill. According to mythology, it was here that Athena and Poseidon fought for control of the city. Inside the temple was a spring of salt water (created by Poseidon's trident) and the mark left by its blow, and nearby grew a sacred olive tree gifted by Athena. The temple is unique for its asymmetrical layout (due to the uneven terrain) and the famous Portico of the Caryatids, where, instead of conventional columns, the roof is supported by six marble figures of maidens.
events.name: Construction of Erechtheion

events.description: Battle of Arginusae sees Athens win but lose 25 ships in storm; Assembly executes six victorious generals for failing to rescue drowning sailors - Socrates alone opposes as unconstitutional
events.name: Battle of Arginusae

events.description: Battle of Aegospotami sees Spartan Lysander destroy Athenian fleet beached for supplies; captures 170 of 180 ships and 3,000-4,000 prisoners, executing all Athenians - war effectively over
events.name: Battle of Aegospotami

events.description: Thirty Tyrants seize power in Athens with Spartan support; oligarchic regime executes 1,500 citizens and exiles 5,000, confiscating property - Critias and Theramenes lead brutal purge
events.name: Rule of Thirty Tyrants

events.description: Athens surrenders to Sparta ending Peloponnesian War; Long Walls demolished to sound of flute music, fleet reduced to 12 ships, and Thirty Tyrants installed - Spartan hegemony begins
events.name: Athens Surrenders

events.description: Democratic exiles led by Thrasybulus overthrow Thirty Tyrants and restore democracy; amnesty declared for all except Thirty and their lieutenants - remarkably peaceful transition
events.name: Exile of Thirty Tyrants

events.description: Trial and execution of Socrates in Athens for 'corrupting youth' and 'introducing new gods'; drinks hemlock after refusing escape, becoming martyr to philosophy and symbol of intellectual freedom
events.name: Death of Socrates

events.description: Corinthian War begins as Thebes, Corinth, Athens, and Argos unite against Spartan hegemony; Persian gold funds anti-Spartan coalition while Persians regain Ionian Greek cities
events.name: Corinthian War Begins

events.description: The battle took place between the Spartan fleet under the command of Pisander and the combined Persian-Athenian fleet under the joint command of the Persian satrap Pharnabazus and the experienced Athenian admiral Conon. The battle ended in complete victory for the Persian-Athenian coalition. The Spartan fleet was almost completely destroyed, and its commander, Pisander, was killed.
events.name: Battle of Cnidus

events.description: The battle took place between Sparta and its allies (the Peloponnesians) on one side and a coalition of Athens, Thebes, Corinth, and Argos on the other. The battle took place near the dry bed of the Nemea River. Although both sides gained victories on certain flanks, overall the Spartan army achieved a decisive victory, inflicting far greater losses on the coalition.
events.name: Battle of Nemea

events.description: Concerned about the resurgence of Athens, Persia changes sides and begins to support Sparta, threatening to block grain supplies to Athens.
events.name: Persia changes side

events.description: Athenian general Iphicrates revolutionizes infantry with peltasts - light-armed troops with javelins defeating Spartan hoplites at Lechaeum; traditional phalanx no longer invincible
events.name: Peltast Revolution

events.description: King's Peace (Peace of Antalcidas) dictated by Persian king Artaxerxes II; Persia regains Ionian Greeks, all Greek cities declared autonomous - effectively ending Spartan and Athenian empires
events.name: King's Peace

events.description: Aristotle born in Stagira, Macedonia; student of Plato for 20 years, tutor to Alexander the Great, and founder of Lyceum - creates systematic knowledge spanning logic, physics, biology, ethics, politics
events.name: Birth of Aristotle

events.description: Sparta seizes Theban citadel Cadmea by treachery during peace; occupies city for three years, enraging Greeks and demonstrating Spartan tyranny over 'autonomous' cities
events.name: Spartan Seizure of Thebes

events.description: The construction of this temple lasted about two centuries and was completed around 380 BC by the architects Demetrius and Paeonius.
events.name: The Temple of Artemis at Ephesus

events.description: Theban democratic exiles led by Pelopidas liberate Thebes from Spartan garrison; conspirators dressed as women infiltrate banquet and kill pro-Spartan oligarchs, triggering war
events.name: Theban Liberation

events.description: Second Athenian League formed as alternative to Spartan hegemony; unlike Delian League, prohibits Athenian ownership of allied land and garrisons, attracting 70 members
events.name: Second Athenian League

events.description: Theban general Epaminondas develops revolutionary oblique order tactics; concentrates 50-deep column on one wing while refusing battle on other, breaking traditional phalanx symmetry
events.name: Epaminondas Oblique Order

events.description: Battle of Leuctra sees Thebes crush Spartan army killing 400 of 700 Spartiates including King Cleombrotus; Epaminondas's oblique order destroys myth of Spartan invincibility forever
events.name: Battle of Leuctra

events.description: Epaminondas invades Peloponnese and liberates Messenia after 300 years of Spartan helot slavery; founds Messene city with 9 km walls, permanently crippling Spartan agricultural base
events.name: Liberation of Messenia

events.description: Philip of Macedon was sent to Thebes as a political hostage (a common practice at the time to ensure peace between states). During these years, he lived in the house of the prominent Theban general Pammenes and had the opportunity to observe the military innovations and tactics developed by the great Theban commander Epaminondas.
events.name: Philip II hostaged by Thebes

events.description: Plato's Academy reaches peak influence in Athens; aristocratic school trains philosophers, mathematicians, and statesmen for 40 years, with Aristotle as most famous student
events.name: Plato's Academy

events.description: Battle of Mantinea sees Epaminondas defeat Spartans and Athenians but die from wound in moment of victory; Theban hegemony dies with him, leaving Greek world fragmented and exhausted
events.name: Battle of Mantinea

events.description: Philip II becomes king of Macedonia at age 23; inherits weak kingdom invaded by Illyrians but will transform it into dominant Greek power through military innovation and diplomacy
events.name: Philip II Becomes King

events.description: The city became part of the Macedonian kingdom. This gave Macedonia access to the Aegean Sea and control over the rich gold mines of Mount Pangaea. The gold from these mines allowed Philip to finance his subsequent large-scale military campaigns and bribe Greek politicians.
events.name: Philip II captures Amphipolis

events.description: Herostratus, a resident of Ephesus, burns down a temple to gain fame. According to legend, Herostratus burned the temple on the same day that Alexander the Great was born, so Artemis was busy. The temple was rebuilt some time later.
events.name: Herostratus burns the temple of Artemis

events.description: Alexander the Great born in Pella to Philip II and Olympias; legend claims Temple of Artemis at Ephesus burns same night because goddess was attending his birth
events.name: Birth of Alexander the Great

events.description: Philip II develops Macedonian phalanx with 6-meter sarissa pikes; lighter armor allows greater mobility while extended reach makes traditional hoplites obsolete - revolution in warfare
events.name: Macedonian Phalanx Developed

events.description: Philip II defeats Phocian Sacred Band at Battle of Crocus Field; 6,000 prisoners drowned as temple-robbers, demonstrating Philip's use of religious propaganda to legitimize conquests
events.name: Battle of Crocus Field

events.description: Young Alexander tames wild horse Bucephalus that no one else could ride, after noticing the horse feared its own shadow; Philip reportedly says 'My son, seek out a kingdom worthy of yourself, for Macedonia is too small for you'
events.name: Alexander Tames Bucephalus

events.description: Aristotle becomes tutor to 13-year-old Alexander at Mieza; teaches philosophy, medicine, and science for 3 years, instilling in future conqueror love of Homer and Greek culture
events.name: Aristotle Tutors Alexander

events.description: 16-year-old Alexander left as regent of Macedonia while Philip campaigns; defeats Maedi rebellion and founds first city Alexandropolis, demonstrating precocious military and administrative ability
events.name: Alexander as Regent

events.description: Philip's attempts to capture the strategically important cities of Perinthus and Byzantium on the Hellespont (Dardanelles) met with strong resistance, supported by Athens and Persia. Although these sieges were unsuccessful, they led to open war between Athens and Macedonia.
events.name: Macedonia Sieges Byzantium

events.description: Philip II defeats combined Athenian-Theban army; 18-year-old Alexander leads decisive cavalry charge destroying Sacred Band of Thebes - Greek independence ends
events.name: Battle of Chaeronea

events.description: League of Corinth formed uniting Greek states under Macedonian leadership; Philip declared hegemon with power to lead Panhellenic campaign against Persia - Greek city-state independence ends
events.name: League of Corinth

events.description: Philip II assassinated at daughter's wedding by bodyguard Pausanias; Alexander becomes king at 20, immediately executes rivals and suppresses rebellions in Thrace and Thebes
events.name: Assassination of Philip II

events.description: Aristotle returns to Athens and founds Lyceum school; teaches while walking in peripatos (covered walkway), giving followers name 'Peripatetics' - systematic research in biology, logic, ethics
events.name: Aristotle Founds Lyceum

events.description: Alexander destroys Thebes as warning to Greeks; city razed except for temples and house of poet Pindar, 30,000 inhabitants sold into slavery - rebellion against Macedon unthinkable
events.name: Destruction of Thebes

events.description: Alexander visits Oracle of Amun at Siwa Oasis in Libyan Desert; priests allegedly greet him as 'son of Amun' (son of Zeus), reinforcing his divine status and claim to Egyptian throne
events.name: Oracle of Siwa - Son of Amun

events.description: Alexander founds Alexandria in Egypt at strategic location on Mediterranean coast; city becomes greatest center of learning and commerce in ancient world, housing famous Library and Lighthouse
events.name: Foundation of Alexandria

events.description: Alexander executes general Philotas for alleged conspiracy, then sends assassins to kill Philotas's father Parmenion, his most experienced commander; first major purge of Macedonian nobility
events.name: Execution of Philotas and Parmenion

events.description: Alexander pursues Bessus into Bactria and Sogdiana (modern Afghanistan/Central Asia); captures and executes Darius's murderer, beginning three years of difficult guerrilla warfare in mountains
events.name: Bactrian Campaign Begins

events.description: Alexander kills his friend and general Cleitus the Black in drunken rage at banquet when Cleitus criticizes his Persian customs adoption; Alexander is consumed by remorse for days
events.name: Murder of Cleitus the Black

events.description: Alexander marries Roxana, Bactrian princess captured at Sogdian Rock fortress; first and most beloved of his wives, she will bear his only legitimate heir after his death
events.name: Marriage to Roxana

events.description: Alexander attempts to introduce proskynesis (Persian ritual prostration) at court; Greek companions refuse to bow as to a god, led by Callisthenes who is later arrested for conspiracy
events.name: Proskynesis Controversy

events.description: Alexander wounded nearly fatally by arrow during assault on Mallian citadel in India; arrow pierces his lung, and he is carried out apparently dead, causing panic among his troops
events.name: Alexander Wounded at Multan

events.description: Alexander's army mutinies at Hyphasis River, refusing to march further into India; exhausted troops weep and beg to return home after 8 years of continuous campaigning - Alexander reluctantly agrees
events.name: Mutiny at Hyphasis River

events.description: Alexander's beloved horse Bucephalus dies after Battle of Hydaspes, either from wounds or old age at 30; Alexander founds city of Bucephala in his honor near modern Jhelum, Pakistan
events.name: Death of Bucephalus

events.description: Alexander defeats Indian King Porus at Battle of Hydaspes despite facing war elephants for first time; impressed by Porus's valor, Alexander restores his kingdom and makes him ally
events.name: Battle of Hydaspes

events.description: Alexander leads army through Gedrosian Desert (Makran) in catastrophic march; thousands die from heat, thirst, and flash floods - some say more troops died here than in all his battles combined
events.name: Gedrosian Desert March

events.description: Hephaestion, Alexander's closest friend and second-in-command, dies of fever at Ecbatana; Alexander's grief is extreme - he crucifies the physician, orders extravagant funeral, and himself dies 8 months later
events.name: Death of Hephaestion

events.description: Macedonian veterans mutiny at Opis against integration of Persian soldiers into army; Alexander dismisses entire army, recruits Persians instead - veterans beg forgiveness and reconciliation follows
events.name: Mutiny at Opis

events.description: Mass wedding at Susa where Alexander and 80 officers marry Persian noblewomen to unite Greek and Persian aristocracy; Alexander takes Darius's daughter Stateira II as second wife
events.name: Greek Weddings at Susa

events.description: Alexander the Great dies in Babylon at age 32 after 10-day fever, possibly from typhoid, poison, or excessive drinking; when asked who should succeed him, reportedly replies 'the strongest'
events.name: Death of Alexander the Great

events.description: Wars of the Diadochi begin as Alexander's generals fight over his empire; Perdiccas, Ptolemy, Seleucus, Antigonus, and Lysimachus carve up territories, destroying Alexander's unified legacy
events.name: Wars of the Diadochi Begin

events.description: Aristotle flees Athens after Alexander's death due to anti-Macedonian sentiment; reportedly says he will not let Athenians 'sin twice against philosophy' (referring to Socrates) - dies in Chalcis same year
events.name: Death of Aristotle

events.description: Ptolemy hijacks Alexander's funeral cortege en route to Macedonia, diverting it to Egypt; Alexander's body eventually displayed in magnificent tomb in Alexandria, becoming pilgrimage site for centuries
events.name: Alexander's Body Taken to Egypt

events.description: Roxana and Alexander IV (Alexander's posthumous son) murdered by Cassander, ending Argead dynasty; all of Alexander's blood relatives systematically eliminated by his former generals
events.name: Murder of Alexander's Family

events.description: The future scientist and engineer, Archimedes was born into the family of the Syracusan mathematician and astronomer Phidias. Archimedes' family and the family of the Syracusan tyrant Hiero II were close, so Archimedes had the opportunity to pursue his science using the resources of the wealthiest Greek city.
events.name: The birth of Archimedes

events.description: Archimedes knew that the perimeter of a hexagon inscribed in a circle is 6R. Using Pythagoras's mathematical knowledge, he successively doubles the number of faces and gradually arrives at a value of œÄ approximated to thousandths, which will be used until the modern era.
events.name: Archimedes derives the pi number

events.description: The treatise is, in fact, the first ever manual on the theory of ship stability: here Archimedes formulates his famous law of displacement, introduces weight and volume into physics as mathematical variables, and mathematically calculates at what angle of inclination a body (ship) will return to a level position, and at what angle it will capsize.
events.name: Archimedes's 'on floating bodies'

events.description: The Syracusia, a cruise ship from antiquity, with its gardens, buildings, and swimming pools on board, symbolizes the power and wealth of Syracuse. Archimedes solves the problem of launching the largest ship in history, using levers and pulleys to control the descent.
events.name: The launch of Syracusia

events.description: In his scientific work, Archimedes proved that the volume and surface area of ‚Äã‚Äãa sphere are exactly two-thirds of the volume and surface area of ‚Äã‚Äãthe cylinder circumscribed around it. Archimedes loved this work so much that he bequeathed this formula to his tomb. The fact that both area and volume were in the same proportion amazed him.
events.name: Archimedes writes 'On the Sphere and Cylinder'
